caption: This statue is an bronze statue of Captain Dreyfus (1859-1935), the famous French officer victimised as part of a judicial conspiracy known as the Dreyfus Affair. The statue is the work of artist Louis Mitelberg and was installed at Place Pierre-Lafue in 1985.  What you see is a expressionist interpretation of Dreyfus in uniform holding up a broken sword with his right hand in front of his face. It is an interesting monument to an equally interesting historic figure. Worth a couple minutes viewing if you happen to pass by.
Impressive sculpture but It should be placed in a more central location.
Could have been in a more prominent location...
This statue could be placed in a more respectable place i.a. in the light of history and out of respect for freedom, zeal towards injustice and known anti-Semitism which is important to oppose.

An interesting sculpture from 1985, the work of Tim, which had difficulty finding a location in Paris. It was not until 1994 that it was finally installed in Square Pierre-Lafue. The statue represents Captain Dreyfus in full length holding his broken saber in front of him, a symbol of his unjust and shameful degradation.

One star less for the lack of maintenance of the small place. The tribute to Captain Alfred Dreyfus is a bronze statue, made in 1985 by Louis Mitelberg known as TIM (1919-2002), located on Place Pierre Lafue Paris 6th. She arrived at this location after a long, uncertain wandering through Paris which lasted almost ten years. A cartel located on the base mentions the name of the work and the artist, the name and date of the public commission and the message "If you want me to live, make me restore my honor" (extract from a letter from Dreyfus to his wife Lucie Dreyfus when he was detained on Devil's Island). A resin copy of the statue was made in 2003 and appears in the courtyard of the Museum of Art and History of Judaism. Another was inaugurated in Tel Aviv - Jaffa on 11/27/2018, not far from the French institute.
I'm rather mixed: I like the silhouette but less the appearance. Well placed on this wooded plot, it deserves cleaning of its base.

Tribute to Captain Dreyfus (1859 – 1935) Statue of the French artist Louis Mitelberg known as Tim, press cartoonist and sculptor, located on Place Pierre Lafue in Paris (6th) Public commission from the Ministry of Culture and La Francophonie in 1985. It represents Alfred Dreyfus, full length, holding his broken saber in front of his face. It is a bronze measuring 3.50 m x 1 m x 0.80 m which was cast by the Clementi workshop in Meudon. A cartel located on the base mentions the name of the work and the artist, the name and date of the public commission, and the message “If you want me to live, make me restore my honor” (extract from a letter from Dreyfus to his wife when he was detained on Devil's Island, from 1895 to 1899). January 13, 1898: Publication of “J’Accuse” by Emile Zola in l’Aurore, an open letter in which the writer denounces a “crime of injustice against humanity” and “crime against justice”. A month later Zola was sentenced to one year in prison. It took Dreyfus 12 years from his arrest on October 15, 1894 to his rehabilitation on July 12, 1906. After several rejected proposals for its installation location, it would be necessary to wait until June 9, 1988 to see the inauguration of the statue at the Jardin des Tuileries, near the so-called “waterfront” terrace. The work was transferred on October 16, 1994 to Place Pierre-Lafue, at the corner of Rue Notre-Dame-des-Champs and Boulevard Raspail, at the initiative of Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris. time, for the centenary of the Arrest of Dreyfus. The Army is still opposed to its transfer to the Military Academy despite the wishes of several personalities. A plaque in his honor was discreetly placed there on February 2, 1998 to celebrate the centenary of “J’Accuse…!” » by Emile Zola.
